Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <juni> ?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @juni what is your question?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @ITM airdrop works on addresses, not wallets, so most likely you have some addresses with smaller amounts of HUSH, that haven't been sent out yet

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <psimondo (ginturk)> Can we pin this on announcements... you might want to see your new address https://dexstats.info/addressconverter.php

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Command line junkies can convert old HUSH `t1` addresses to new HUSH3 `R` addresses with this tool I wrote: https://github.com/MyHush/hush3/blob/duke/contrib/convert_address.py

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <blankmac - BasementPool> @dukeleto  The private key is the same tho, correct?  Or no?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @blankmac - BasementPool no, the public and private keys have different base58 prefixes, so they look different, but they are the same key, encoded differently

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @blankmac - BasementPool KMD Agama GUI wallet has a "WIF to WIF" tool in the "Tools" menu

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it can translate WIFs between coins

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <blankmac - BasementPool> Ah, I see, so I can translate the private key with your script?  Or another tool?  Just trying to understand how to import my old address balances.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> current agama only knows about old hush, so if you use an existing agama, you would say "convert this HUSH WIF to this KMD WIF"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> my script only converts addresses

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> there is a script to convert wifs too, the Agama GUI is probably easier to use

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Current HUSH3 WIF format, as an asset chain, is KMD format, like every other asset chain

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> KMD and all asset chains use the same base58 prefixes for addresses (normal and scripthash), public keys, and private keys

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> HUSH old format was exactly the same as ZEC. With the above information, it's possible to use existing tools or write new ones to do it, but it needs to be made easier

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> we are working on that

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> another simple thing, is to backup your wallet.dat

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and then use an old HUSH wallet.dat on a new HUSH3 full node, with the `-zapwallettxes` CLI arg, which should allow you to claim funds. Obviously we need to test this more and it's only for people comfortable with the CLI

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> various exchanges and pools have been doing things like this, to get operational

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Because all BTC forks share the same math curve, they have the same public + private keys, so your wallet.dat unlocks equivalent addresses on any chain

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <blankmac - BasementPool> Ok, my skull is thick but I think it got through...lol.   So I can use the KMD agama wallet to translate the old hush priv key and then use that to import to the full node?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> yes

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> "Tools" menu of KMD agama desktop wallet

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> has many things, one is "Wif to Wif"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> WIF=Wallet Import Format

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> which is base58 of a privatey key, which some prefixes

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> never give a WIF to anybody! You should never give it to a website!

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Only because you trust the wallet running on your computer, and it has access to all your funds already, is why putting in a WIF is ok. It's a completely local operation

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> You only should ever use a WIF yourself, never give it to others, is what I am trying to say

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <blankmac - BasementPool> Gotcha, I'm clear on the security aspects of the private key.   I do some hardware programming as a hobby so I'm not completely out to lunch, but admittedly, my knowledge of the nuts and bolts of crypto is lacking for sure.

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <ComputerGenie - ChickenPool> _starts a movement where "private key" and "wif" aren't interchangeable in conversations_

And somebody soon will probably print infinite sprout money on the old chain, just for fun. There is a reason we upgraded! :carlos:
